messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] Aesthetic Concerns for a new font.
I'm elated to see someone undertake this task.   QS has an intrinsic beauty which is, alas, not captured in the clunky Jerome font.  I have been at work on a substitute myself for some time, using more calligraphic forms.  I too found linkages a major stumbling block.

More general thoughts later, but first:

In direct reply to your first query, I take "mere" to be exactly 27-36-25. That is, it is a quickly pronounced two syllable word "mi-er", (it's not like the French word "mer," 29-25) and it is written with the "er" combination, as Read details it in the middle of page 10 ("baker, gather, etc").  While certain dialects and purists may disagree here, as Read puts it "any subtle distinctions between these sounds are neither heard not spelt successfully and consistently by all writers."

Now on to a larger issue: It appears to me that the issue of "half-letters" needs addressing directly at the start of your project. Their adoption in handwriting is designed to increase speed in writing and, I suspect, just because they are pretty and add to the visual flow of the script.

But what is being designed here is a computer font, and it does not have to ape the calligraphy of the hand written word.  Just as Medieval calligraphers drove themselves to distraction trying to ape with their quill pens the Roman letters carved with chisels in the stone on Trajan's column, and so wound up inventing the uncials, which took full advantage of their medium, we are now at a juncture in history where we are in danger of trying to ape QS calligraphy while punching keys on a keyboard.

It all depends on what you want to achieve: if, as in hand-done QS, it's all about efficiency and minimal "pen lifts" or keystrokes, then any computer alphabet that takes two keystrokes, or a key combination, to write one phoneme is just plain silly.  Better to use the 40 letters of junior QS assigned to 40 keys, while adopting only the abbreviated spelling conventions of Senior QS, and casting the half-letters to the wind.

On the other hand, if beauty and display are the main goals of writing QS on a computer, then the number of keystrokes be damned. Hail to the half-letters, and any other myriad linkages that may be thought of!

(If goal 2 is the one you choose, a suggestion here:  the Jerome font seems to have been designed in a Luddite manner, as if for a 1900 Smith Corona, utilizing only the good old shift key for odd characters.  If one acknowledges that we are indeed designing for a computer keyboard, then we have the Command (or Apple), Option, and Control Keys at our disposal, all within a quarter inch of the old Shift key..  Thus every basic character could have 4 variations, instead of 1, and still reside on a logical home key.)

Another question that arises: should the sounds be assigned to the QWERTY arrangement of letters (another Luddite scheme if there ever was on, but advantageous for those that look at the keyboard) or should they be assigned according to phoneme frequency of use, requiring minimal finger movement, a la Dvorak? Could we have a referendum on that please? (I do have some pseudo-scientific information on phoneme frequency.)

And finallly, one request: in your work don't forget us Mac users when you do publish your font.

Good luck!







Hello all.  I am designing a replacement truetype font for Jerome.
This new font (called KINGSLEY.TTF) will include (among other things)
a more intuitive keyboard layout based on a one-to-one conversion
between the sounds of T.O. and Readscript, characters with standard
stroke widths and joining points, and kerning pairs that provide what
I perceive to be the best representation of the way Readscript was
meant to be written.

For consistency's sake, I am currently going to be the only active
developer until the font reaches a suitable beta release state, but I
would like the input and participation of all Readscript enthusiasts
in this endeavor, such that we can truely have a font written
by-enthusiasts-for-enthusiasts and one that we can all have some
amount of personal involvement and satisfaction in.

There are, of course, stumbling blocks to be overcome and questions
about standardization that need to be asked, so I have decided to ask
them here and now (even though the characters are only about halfway
finished).

To kick things off, my first question to the quickscript community
regards the joining of characters to letter #25/Roe.

As is plainly seen, the character was designed with two joining
points, both of which are incoming points and exist on the same
x-plane.  It shares the first of these properties with #22/May, and
shares both of these properties with only one other character:
#37/OUt. This introduces problems in font design when being connected
to by any characters that cross into the x-plane through or beyond
both joining sites (i.e. #'s 3, 7, 10, 14, 26, 27).  When examined
further, however, one notes that most of these characters would NEVER
join to #25, except perhaps #7 or #27.  I have noticed on page 13 of
the Quickscript Manual that there seemes to be an extra character #36
in the example "mere" (27-36-25).  Is this really #36, or one of the
"confusing linking strokes" that Read talks about?  If it IS #36, is
this because of English pronunciation?

Thanks, and I look forward to further input in participation in this
project
